CARDINAL . The relevant provisions of the LAW concerning the quashing of final and enforceable decisions and the reopening of civil cases , read as follows :

“ Proceedings terminated by a final judgment ( decision ) may be reopened only if there are grounds for bringing either a request to render the final judgment null and void ( LAW ) or a request to reopen the proceedings in view of newly discovered circumstances ( LAW ) . ”
“ CARDINAL . A final and binding judgment ( decision ) may be quashed at the request of the interested party , if :
( a ) A judge who participated in the deliberations in the case was barred from doing so by operation of law ;
( b ) One of the parties , or its representative in law , had not been invited to participate in the examination of the case .

CARDINAL . The request to render a final judgment null and void on the above - mentioned grounds shall not be entertained if the requesting party could have referred to those grounds during the proceedings , before the first instance , appeal or cassation courts . ”

Pursuant to LAW ORG , a request for reopening of proceedings should be lodged within DATE after the party concerned learns of the grounds which might either render the final decision null and void or represent newly discovered circumstances within the meaning of LAW . That period was not extendable . LAW CARDINAL further specified that , in a situation envisaged by LAW ( b ) , the period of DATE started to run following the formal notification of the decision to the party to the proceedings or , if appropriate , its representative in law .

Article CARDINAL § CARDINAL of the ORG stated that an appeal lay against a decision dismissing a request for quashing . However , neither that Article nor any other provision in the Code provided for the possibility of appealing against a decision granting such a request . Pursuant to LAW , the merits of a request for quashing must be examined at an oral hearing .
